newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysia Air raising 50 bln yen in notes.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia Air raising 50 bln yen in notes.

text.p: National carrier Malaysian Airline System Bhd (MAS) said it has signed agreements with 18 predominantly Japanese financial institutions to raise 50 billion yen in debt.

The airline said in a statement issued late on Monday it is raising 40 billion yen in a fixed-rate Euroyen issue, and another 10 billion yen in a floating rate note (FRN) issue through its wholly-owned financing vehicle, Malaysia Airlines Capital (Labuan) Ltd.
The five-year fixed-rate issue has a coupon rate of 2.55 percent.
The five-year FRN pays a coupon of six-month yen Libor (London Interbank Offered Rate) plus 25 basis points.
MAS said Malaysia Airlines Capital is rated A+ by Japanese rating agency Nippon Investors Service Inc.

Both issues attracted a diversified syndicate group with Daiwa Securities (HK) Ltd heading the management group for the fixed-rate issue. Daiwa is also the joint lead manager with Sanwa International Finance Ltd on the FRN.
The fixed-rate issue was increased from the original size of 30 billion yen to 40 billion due to oversubscription and favourable investor reception, MAS said.

The lead manager placed its allocation predominantly to Japanese investors, with investment trust and corporates accounting for over 60 percent of the total placement. Others included trust and regional banks, life/non-life insurance and credit cooperatives, the statement said.
